Sorry to see you go, I enjoyed our chat!
Ok bye then! Enjoy the rest of your day!
Had a nice time talking with you!

Thank you!

You've been very helpful

Very kind of you to help me
responses: No problem at all!
You are very welcome!
Anytime!

patterns: How are you
You good
Are you well
How's it going
What's good
You alright
How are you feeling
responses: I am very well thank you!
I'm great thanks for asking!

patterns: What is your name
What did your parents call you
What should I call you
What should I refer to you as?
What's your name
Who are you
responses: My name is Bonnie!
You can call me Bonnie!

patterns: Can you be my friend
I want to be your friend
Let's be friends
Will you be my friend
I have no friends, so can you be my friend
I want another friend
Wanna be friends??
responses: I would love to be your friend!
Of course we can be friends!

patterns: what do you do
what is your purpose
What are you for
why do you exist
How can you help me
What can you do
responses: My purpose is to answer any questions you may have about Coronavirus
I can provide you with information about COVID-19!

patterns: Whats your favourite football team
Favourite team???
favourite football team
What is the name of your favourite football team?
responses: Liverpool
Manchester City

patterns: Am I a high risk individual?
Am I at high risk of Coronavirus?
Am I classified as being at high risk?
Is my grandparent at high risk?
Am I high risk
How can I be high risk
responses: You are at risk if any of the following apply to you:
Aged 70 and over
Have a long term condition
Have had an organ transplant
If you are being shielded
Pregnant

patterns: What is high risk
What is the definition of high risk
Can you explain high risk
responses: High risk is when you are clinically extremely vulnerable to COVID-19

patterns: What is coronavirus
What is covid-19
What is coronavirus
Define coronavirus
Can you explain coronavirus
responses: Coronavirus (or Covid-19) is in a family of viruses including the common cold and other respitory illnesses
It affects your airways and lungs
The effects are mild for many however it can be very severe

patterns: How does Coronavirus spread?
How is Coronavirus transmitted
How can I catch coronavirus
In what way does coronavirus spread
responses: There are two ways in which Coronavirus can be spread:
A person can touch a surface that an infected person has touched
A person gets close to (less than 1-2 metres) to an infectious person

patterns: What is the average incubation period
How long do symptoms take to develop
How long does it take for symptoms to show
After how much time would I develop Coronavirus after being infected
responses: The average incubation period of COVID-19 is 5 days, but it could be between 1 and 14 days

patterns: How long should I self-isolate for
How long should I be in self isolation for
What is the recommended time for self isolation
How long should I isolate if I am infected
How long should I self isolate if a family member is infected
responses: You should self-isolate for at least 7 days if you are infected
If a household member has symptoms you should self-isolate for 14 days

patterns: What are the symptoms
What are the symptoms of Coronavirus
How can I tell if I have coronavirus
What symptoms would I have if I have corona?
If I have covid what are the symptoms
responses: The most common symptoms are a persistent/dry cough and a high temperature (37.7°C or above)
Other symptoms may include:
Shortness of breath
A sore throat
A blocked/runny nose
Stomach discomfort and diarrhoea
Loss of taste and smell

intents.tag: unwell what should I do long
patterns: If I'm unwell what should I do?
If I have coronavirus symptoms what should I do
If I'm ill with coronavirus what should I do?
If i have symptoms
I have symptoms
responses: If you are classed as extremely vulnerable and have symptoms call NHS at 111
If not you can use the following link to check your symptoms and access support
https://111.nhs.uk/covid-19/
You should also consider alerting people you have close contact within the last 48 hours to let them know you have symptoms

patterns: Can I be tested
Am I eligible to be tested?
Can I get a test for Coronavirus
Can I get tested
Am I allowed to get a test
responses: You are eligible for a test if any of the following apply to you:
Aged 65 and over and displaying symptoms of Coronavirus
Unable to work from home and displaying symptoms of Coronavirus
All NHS and social care staff
All care home residents and people being discharged from hospital into care homes

intents.tag: how can I get a test
patterns: How do I book a test
How can I get a test?
How should I organise a test
Can I get a test
responses: If you're eligible you can book a test at https://self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk/test-type

patterns: How can I reduce my risk of catching or spreading coronavirus
How can I prevent getting coronavirus
How do I not get coronavirus
How do I stop myself from spreading coronavirus
How to stop spreading covid
How to prevent catching coronavirus
How can i not get coronavirus
responses: Stay at least 2 metres away from other people when outside your house
Wash your hands frequently and thoroughly
Cover your face when using public transport or in a crowded shop
Stay at home!

patterns: How often should I wash my hands
When should I wash my hands
After what activities should I wash my hands
responses: Wash your hands:
When you get home after going out
Before eating or handling food
After sneezing or blowing your nose

patterns: What should I do about my current medical treatments
What should I do about my upcoming appointments
What should I do if I am unwell with existing medical conditions
How can I get my medical treatments
responses: If you are unwell you can still speak to your GP although this would have to be over the phone
If you have a treatment plan you should continue to follow it
Some appointments have been postponed although your appointments may still be ongoing so contact your GP for clarification

patterns: When am I allowed to leave my house?
When can I leave my home?
In what circumstances can I go outside?
When can I go out?
When can I leave home?
When can I leave my house
responses: You are allowed to leave your home except in the following circumstances:
To visit friends and family inside their homes
Staying overnight away from your own home
Exercising in an indoor sports court/leisure centre/gym/pool
Using an outdoor gym or playground
Gather outdoors in a group of more than six

patterns: What does social distancing mean?
What is the meaning of social distancing?
Define social distancing
What is social distancing
Can you explain social distancing
responses: Social distancing is staying at home and only leaving for a few reasons defined by the government. When you are outside your home you should stay at least two metres away from other people

patterns: What does self-isolation mean?
What is the meaning of self isolation?
Define self-isolation
What is self-isolation
Can you explain self-isolation
responses: Self-isolation is avoiding contact with others (even those you live with) and not leaving your home for any reason. You should do this if you are displaying symptoms or live with somebody displaying symptoms

patterns: What does shielding mean?
What is the meaning of shielding?
Define shielding
What is shielding
Can you explain shielding
responses: Shielding is a type of self-isolation which involves not leaving your home for any reason until the end of June to reduce your risk of contracting COVID-19

patterns: Do I have to social distance
Do I have to do social distancing
Am I required to do social distancing?
Why should I social distance
Why am i social distancing
responses: Everyone should be social distancing. If you are over 70 or have existing health conditions try to stay home regardless

patterns: Do I have to do shielding
Do I have to be shielded
Should I be shielding?
I am at high risk, should I be shielding
responses: Anyone who has been identified as extremely vulnerable or high risk should be shielded

patterns: Can I talk to someone to get support?
Can I speak to someone to get help?
How can I get support?
What support is there
Where can I talk to someone for support?
How can I get support for coronavirus
I need support
responses: You can use the link at the top of the screen labelled Coronavirus Support Line (hover over COVID-19 Websites) which will bring you to a page with an email and phone number which you can use to talk to someone

patterns: I need mental health help
I'm concerned about my dad's mental health
I'm worried about my mum's mental health
I'm scared for my mental health
Can I talk to someone about my mental health
responses: The NHS has provided a list of helplines you can contract for expert advice. The link to the NHS page is on the COVID-19 Website dropdown labelled 'Mental Health Helplines

patterns: How many cases
How many cases of COVID-19 are there in
How many cases
How many deaths
How many coronavirus cases in
How many coronavirus deaths in
How many cases in
How many cases of coronavirus are there in
How many deaths of coronavirus are there in
How many cases of coronavirus
How many deaths of coronavirus
responses: Simply type the name of the country/UK area and Bonnie should reply with the number of coronavirus cases if you have typed in a valid location. A list of supported areas is available at the top of the page

patterns: Who created you
Who made you
Who made the website
Who made the chatbot
Who made Bonnie Bot
responses: Two students of Eton College created me because their GCSEs and A levels were cancelled
They decided to use their new found time to create a chatbot which provides information on the current pandemic, COVID-19.

patterns: What are the conspiracy theories surrounding coronavirus
Does 5G cause coronavirus
Does 5G cause COVID-19
Do 5G waves assist the transmission of coronavirus
Should I burn 5G towers
Why does 5G cause coronavirus
responses: There is currently a conspiracy theory circulating around saying that 5G waves assist in the transmission of COVID-19
However there is no scientific evidence to support this claim.

patterns: How can I help tackle coronavirus?
Is there anything I can do to help?
Are there any ways I can volunteer
I'd like to volunteer to help fight against coronavirus
How can I help
What can I do to help?
responses: The best way you can help is of course to stay at home!
There are other ways you can help though
If you would like to donate there are many great charities providing help to those particularly affected
There are also other charities which provide ways for you to volunteer in your local area with vulnerable people or the NHS
We would like to encourage you to research yourselves and find what suits you best!

patterns: Can I meet with friends and family in the park
Am I allowed to go to the park
Can I go to an outdoor park
Can I go to the park?
responses: You can meet in a group of up to six people if you are outdoors. You should stay at least 2 metres away from the people you do not live with

patterns: Can I play sport with someone I live with
Can I play tennis with a friend
Can I play cricket with my family
Am I allowed to play outdoors sport with people I don't live with
Can I play sport
Can I do sport
Can i play sport in the park
Can i play sport with a friend
responses: You can exercise or play sport in groups of up to six people from other households, but you should try to keep 2 metres between you when you can. You should keep sharing equipment to a minimum and make sure to clean equipment thoroughly

patterns: Am I allowed to sit in someone's back garden?
Can I sit in a friend's garden?
Can I go to a garden
Can I go to my friend's garden
responses: You are allowed to spend time in gardens and other private outdoor spaces in groups of up to 6 people from different households

patterns: How far can I travel for exercise or outdoor activity
Are there restrictions on how far I can travel
Where can I travel
How can I travel
responses: There are no restrictions on how far you can travel but you should return the same night

patterns: Can I visit outdoor tourist sites?
Can I go to tourist locations?
Can I go to touristic places
Can I vist tourist sites
responses: You can still travel to outdoor tourist locations, however some indoor sites may not be allowed to open

patterns: Can weddings go ahead?
Are we allowed to have a wedding?
Can we get married and have a wedding?
Can I have a wedding?
Can my wedding go ahead
responses: You can not have a wedding. The government has said that it is still not possible to gather in sufficient numbers indoors to enable a wedding ceremony.

patterns: Can I pray in a place of worship
Can I go to a place of worship to pray?
Am I allowed to go to a church
Am I allowed to go a mosque
Am I allowed to go to a synagogue
Am I allowed to go to a temple to worship
Can I worship in
Can I go to a place of worship?
responses: No. It is still not possible to go to any place of worship

patterns: When am I allowed to go back to work
When can I go to work
Who is permitted to go to work?
When can I go back to work
responses: Those in essential retail where work can only be done in the workplace may be permitted to work
Essential retail includes but is not limited to the following:
Supermarkets
Those in construction and manufacturing
Those working in labs and research facilities
Those administering takeways and deliveries
Tradesmen and cleaners
Those who are facilitating trade or transport goods

patterns: Who are critical workers?
What is a critical worker?
Who is defined as a critical worker
Who can be a critical worker
responses: Critical workers are those working in health and care and other essential services
They can send their children to school/childcare regardless of their year group

patterns: When will pubs open
When can I go to the pub
When can I go to the cinema
When will cinemas open
When can I go to the hairdressers
When will hairdressers open
When can I get a haircut
When can i go to the theatre?
responses: Businesses such as pubs/cinemas/hairdressers will not open until Step 3 is reached. This is projected to be July 4 at the earliest

patterns: Do I need to wear a face covering at work?
Should I wear a face covering to work
Am I required to wear a face mask to work
Should I wear a face mask
Should I wear face coverings
responses: Face coverings are not compulsory, however it is recommended that you wear one in enclosed public spaces where social distancing is not possible

patterns: Who is allowed to travel on public transport?
Am I allowed to use public transport
Can I use public transport to get to work
Can I go on public transport
responses: If you cannot work from home and have to travel to work, you can use public transport if it is your only option. If possible, try to reduce travel and cycle/walk as much as possible

patterns: When can my child go back to school
When can my son return to school
When can my daughter go to University
Are schools open
When are schools reopening
When can I go to school
When do schools open
responses: From Monday 1st June all early year settings can reopen and schools can start welcoming back pupils in Reception/Year 1/Year 6 in smaller class sizes
From Monday 15th June pupils in Year 10 and 12 will prepare to begin some face to face support with teachers

patterns: Will my child be safe at school
What measure are being put in place to make sure my child is safe at school?
How are schools going to be made safe
What changes are being made to schools to make them safe
Are schools safe
Should I send my kids to school
responses: Protective measures for schools include:
Regular hand cleaning
Hygiene and cleaning measure
Small consistent group and class sizes of no more than 15 pupils
Schools have also been asked to consider:
Stagger arrival times/break times/assemblies
Making use of outdoor space

patterns: How will police enforce the rules
What are the fines
How are the rules going to be enforced
What will happen if I break the rules
responses: The Police will act with discretion in applying the following measures, however they have the power to disperse you, make you leave an area, issue you with a fixed penalty, or arrest you
The fines are listed below:
First offence - £100 (£50 if paid within 14 days)
Second offence - £200
Third offence - £400
Fourth offence - £800
Fifth offence - £1600
Maximum penalty - £3200

patterns: Is it risky to touch a delivery
Should I touch my shopping
Can I touch other people
Can i touch stuff
Will I get coronavirus if I touch something
responses: You will not contract COVID-19 by touching something
As long as you clean the object you are touching and as long as you wash your hands afterwards.

patterns: How long does coronavirus stay in the air
how long does coronavirus survive?
How long does coronavirus survive on other surfaces
Does coronavirus survive outside the body
How long does coronavirus survive on plastic
How long does coronavirus survive on cardboard
How long does coronavirus survive on metal
responses: The following are examples of how long COVID-19 survives on different surfaces
Air : Half an hour
A fine mist : 3 hours or more
Copper surfaces : Up to 4 hours
Cardboard surfaces : Up to 24 hours
Plastic and Stainless Steel : At least 72 hours

patterns: When does the premier league return
When does the prem return
When is the premier league returning?
When is football restarting?
When can I watch premier league football
On what date is the prem restarting
when does football return
when does the prem return
when is football back
responses: The Premier League is returning on the 17th June

patterns: What is the probability of catching coronavirus
Will I get coronavirus
Am i going to get coronavirus
What is the probability
responses: There is not a recognised probability of catching coronavirus although some people say that at the peak of the pandemic you have a 1 in 1300 chance of catching it.
However, this risk is significantly reduced if you obey government guidlines and significantly increased if you don't!
